items.title: Hummingbirds Are Lovely Loners, Drawn to New York City’s Parks in Fall
items.abstract: The city’s most commonly seen species, the ruby-throated hummingbird (Archilochus colubris), is a tiny bird; insect-like and intricate. It is also asocial.

items.title: Review: How Laws of Physics Govern Growth in Business and in Cities
items.abstract: In his new book, “Scale,” Geoffrey West, a theoretical physicist, manages to deliver a lot of theory and history accessibly and entertainingly.
keywords: Scale: The Universal Laws of Growth, Innovation, Sustainability and the Pace of Life in Organisms, Cities, Economies, and Companies (Book)

items.title: CPR Survival Rates Can Differ Greatly by City
items.abstract: Improvements remain underused in practice. As a result, survival rates after cardiac arrest vary as much as 500 percent across the country.

items.title: Kengo Kuma’s Architecture of the Future
items.abstract: Rejecting flashy forms in favor of buildings in harmony with their environment, the architect is trying to reinvent his entire trade.
